course.@descr: Physical, chemical and biological properties of soils; soil formation, classification, use and conservation. There are no prerequisites for this course, but background in Biology 12, Chemistry 12, and Physics 12 (or first-year university-level) is strongly advised.

Contemporary use of animals for food production, companionship, recreation and science; social and ethical issues concerning human impacts on animals; animals in human culture; protection of animals by society and the law.
course.@prereqnote: At least third-year standing in any faculty.

course.@title: Summer Practicum in Sustainable Agriculture and Food Systems
course.@descr: Based at the UBC Farm. Application required. Fees will be assessed to meet expenses.
Development and implementation of multi-disciplinary pest management programs in agricultural crops.

course.@title: Field Study of Wine Grape Production
course.@descr: Lectures, field trips, laboratory sessions focused on major issues related to grape and wine production. Origin of grape varieties and rootstocks, morphological features of the grapevine, training systems, canopy management strategies, berry composition, the impact of terroir on wine quality. Credit will be granted for only one of PLNT 542, APBI 442 OR APBI 443.

Biodiversity indicators and basic monitoring methods. Sources of agroecosystem biodiversity, including plants, insects, soil invertebrates, and vertebrates. Proficiency in using techniques to measure key abiotic factors in the field.
course.@prereqs: One of BIOL 300, GEOG 374, FRST 231, LFS  252.

course.@title: Applied Animal Biology Practicum - APBI PRACTICUM
course.@descr: Application of principles and concepts of Applied Animal Biology to experiential learning in the fields of wild, companion, lab, and farm animal welfare and management.
course.@prereqnote: Third-year standing or higher. APBI 314 and/or APBI 315 are recommended.

course.@title: Applied Animal Biology Practicum - APBI PRACTICUM
course.@descr: Application of principles and concepts of Applied Animal Biology to experiential learning in the fields of wild, companion, lab, and farm animal welfare and management.
course.@prereqnote: Third-year standing or higher. APBI 314 and/or APBI 315 are recommended.

course.@descr: Preparation of a comprehensive and analytical review of an approved topic under the supervision of a faculty member. Consultation with a program advisor is required.
Design and execution of an experimental/analytical research project leading to the preparation of a thesis.
course.@prereqnote: Approval of a program advisor; consult before the end of classes in third year.

course.@title: Integrated Physiology for Human Nutrition II
course.@descr: Basic principles in human physiology, including function of the cardiovascular, immune, respiratory, urinary and reproductive systems, integration across systems, maintenance of homeostasis, and application to human nutrition.
course.@prereqnote: FNH 160 and 161 together are credit-excluded with BIOL 153 and 155.

course.@descr: Chemical and physical properties of foods; issues pertaining to safety, nutritive value and consumer acceptability; government regulations pertaining to food safety, quality and additives; preservation techniques and transformation of agricultural commodities to food products; foods of the future.
course.@prereqnote: At least second year standing required.

course.@descr: Fundamental concepts and principles of human nutrition applied to current nutrition issues.
course.@prereqs: Either (a) one of BIOL 111, BIOL 112, BIOL 153, BIOL 155 or (b) all of KIN  131, KIN  132.

course.@descr: Principles of viticulture, enology, and wine microbiology and chemistry; marketing, regulation and classification of wines from selected regions of the world; social, economic and health aspects of wine consumption; wine appreciation.
Conceptualization and scientific analyses of global problems in food and nutrition; complexities of food habits and malnutrition in various cultures around the world.

course.@title: International Field Studies in Policy Analysis for Agriculture and Natural Resources
course.@descr: Field studies carried out abroad under the direction of the instructor. Students will be guided to apply selected tools for analysis of agricultural and natural resource policy in developing countries with input from local policymakers. Participating students are assessed a fee.
course.@prereqnote: Third year standing and permission of instructor. 9 credits of upper level ECON, FRE or COMM courses are strongly recommended.
